the ooze singer songwriter archie

with his former band zukid before
changing over to the
pseudonym king cruel which eventually

a 2013 debut album six feet beneath the
moon
and he has a new record out full length
four years later
an album i was excited for especially
considering that
his debut was so good sure it sounded

even at this early point in his career
archie's music had a lot of bold and

the woozy dreamy rock instrumentation
his shouty
bellowing vocals his expressive
performances
and yeah while he did lay it on a little

i assumed that king cruel could really
only go up from here
especially considering how wild and

half-shark
and dumb surfer but this this album is
not the bold
sharp focused effort that i was hoping
for it's 19 tracks
it's just over an hour long and nearly
every song
here is barely a song this record is
really
more of a series of vague moody musical
sketches that
lack any real sense of direction it's
like something that constantly hints
toward a song or gives the audience the
impression that
a song is soon coming but uh
never really comes to fruition instead
of doing that nearly every song here
kind of hangs in this weird
awkward musical purgatory where it's
it's not so developed that it becomes
something but it's not so underdeveloped
that it sounds like nothing
it's kind of like watching a young

and he just he just does not know which

uh it doesn't really build up in
anything compelling

gray blase uniform

it was just so easy to get impatient
with this thing it was so aimless so
downtrodden and while i can appreciate
how potent the sadness on this record is
without any compelling songs to really
kind of carry or
guide any of that emotion it just spills
in every direction and doesn't
really collect into anything significant
like whatever
intense feelings are fueling this album
it's it's so strong to the point where
it's actually debilitating
uh to the performances and to the
writing process this record is kind of
like a shade or two above
a total stranger just sitting down next

spilling out onto you every single
horrible thing that's been happening to
them over the past week or so there are
a handful of very colorful and
interesting highlights on this thing
like the
schmaltzy and fun dumb surfer the very
quirky and animated visual
which is easily one of the most

here
and i really like the sinister and

even tracks on here that hit a pretty

even they hit a point of
tediousness where they just fail to
continue developing into

or check one and there are numerous

is not really bringing the vocal fire he
typically does on a lot of these tracks
either his performances are sleepier
than ever
like on the song lonely blue his singing
just is not engaging in any way

tune out of what the album is trying to
do or
trying not to do at this point i can't

nearly every track here at least to some
degree
i mean if you took the best moments this
entire album has to offer
you would have a pretty good ep and
honestly it's not even simply that the
album is too slow
or that it's too patience testing uh the
title track on here is a highlight for

spacier tracks on the entire record but
there's actually a sharp vocal melody to
this track there is a coherent
progression to this track it reaches an
emotional intensity point that's
very satisfying it's not like archie is
just delivering some kind of
sound bed or musical motif and just
letting it hang there and meander to the
point where he and the band get sick of
it moments like the title track that
actually amplify and empower
the sorrow and the anguish that is
fueling this record
are just too few and far between and

as disappointing
